thread.title: Texas & Neighbors: Moody Gardens becomes an ice paradise
thread.title_full: Texas & Neighbors: Moody Gardens becomes an ice paradise | Dallas Morning News

author: MARY DUNKLIN
title: Texas & Neighbors: Moody Gardens becomes an ice paradise
text:
ABBEVILLE, LA.
Egg celebration is an annual ode to the omelette
Some people like eggs. Others really, really like eggs and want to celebrate in a gigantic way. Those folks should make the trek to Abbeville for the 5,000 Egg Giant Omelette Celebration on Nov. 7-8.
There’s even an official Sunday Mass for the event at St. Mary Magdalen Catholic Church, where the eggs, bread and festival itself are blessed. Highlights of the event include watching the preparation of the omelette and eating the free samples on Sunday. Don’t miss the other food vendors, entertainment, art show, music and more throughout the weekend.
Traveler’s tip: The event takes place in Vermilion Parish, which also offers bird-watching, crawfish eating and plantation touring this time of year, so consider adding those activities during your visit.
Contact: giantomelette.org ; mostcajun.com
Mary Dunklin
DENVER
Film lovers can get their fix at 12-day festival
Plan an end-of-the-year getaway to Colorado in time for the Denver Film Festival, Nov. 4-15.
The event, which attracts nearly 55,000 filmgoers, is screening more than 200 independent films. Other offerings include industry panels, workshops, achievement awards and tributes. The full 12-day program will be announced Oct. 19.
The Sie FilmCenter will be the anchor venue for the fest with all red-carpet presentations at the Ellie Caulkins Opera House.
Tickets go on sale to Denver Film Society members on Oct. 21 and online to the public on Oct. 23.
Contact: d enverfilm.org/festival
NEW ORLEANS
Crescent City fest welcomes readers of all ages
The New Orleans Book Festival offers family-friendly fun for readers of all ages. The free event includes panel discussions, children’s activities, live music and more.
Enjoy an outdoor show from 6:30 to 8 Friday night on the Latter Branch Library lawn at 5120 St. Charles Ave.
On Saturday, visit the shores of Big Lake at City Park from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. for more book-themed fun. Visit with local and national authors and stay for live readings.
Every child who attends will get free books, snacks and bus transportation.
Plus, the nearby New Orleans Museum of Art is offering half-price admission the days of the event.
Contact: nolabookfest.org
GALVESTON
Moody Gardens will transform into a paradise of ice
A team of master carvers is transforming 2 million pounds of ice at Moody Gardens into Ice Land: Ice Sculptures With SpongeBob SquarePants. The attraction will be open Nov. 14 through Jan. 10.
More than 100,000 guests visited the inaugural Ice Land last year. The theme this year is SpongeBob’s Christmas Party, where guests can walk through a full-size Krusty Krab, explore an all-ice Flying Dutchman pirate ship and see other sites made famous by the Nickelodeon cartoon. Plus, last year’s popular 100-foot ice slides will be back with an all-new sled race.
Admission is $26.95 for adults, $21.95 for seniors (65 and older) and $15.95 for children (4-14). A $5 discount is available Sunday through Thursday Nov. 15-Dec. 17, excluding Thanksgiving. Other holiday attractions on-site include the Festival of Lights, ice skating and a gift market.
Contact: 1-800-582-4673; moodygardens.org
